awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of New Urban Planning on Indigenous Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
As more and more indigenous people move to metropolitan areas at rapid rates, municipalities are confronted with urban planning challenges that must balance a range of stakeholder concerns: the infrastructural needs of the city, the stress that is placed on resources, and the importance of preserving the heritage that draws so many people to cities to make them creative centers. This project explores the relocation of a group of indigenous migrants, and how planners develop architectures designed to permit these groups to flourish as urban indigenous subjects with distinct cultural traditions. This project, which trains a graduate student in conducting rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, asks how such urban planning initiatives targeted at urban indigenous populations contribute to cultural and socioeconomic transformation. The results will be useful to engineers, architects, policymakers, and urban officials tasked with the responsibility of building and managing these systems.

Stanford University doctoral candidate, Tomonori Sugimoto, under the guidance of Dr. Miyako Inoue, explores the construction of  new built environments for urban indigenous people. The researcher will conduct research on one such urban planning project targeted at the urban indigenous population in the Taipei region, Taiwan. In Taiwan, close to 50% of the Austronesian indigenous population has settled in metropolitan areas. In 2014, Taipei's suburban municipality of New Taipei City initiated experimental projects to relocate several indigenous squatter communities located on state-owned riverbanks to newly-built "indigenous cultural park areas." The researcher will investigate the ideals and intentions of city officials and architects in relocating indigenous squatters to these new communities. In addition, the researcher will examine what kinds of impacts relocation to new communities might have on community residents' cultures, livelihoods, and community. The researcher will employ methods such as in-depth interviews with city officials, architects, and community residents, participant observation of community meetings and city council meetings, analysis of expert architectural knowledge, and archival research. This research will further our understanding of how urbanization is affecting indigenous communities, a topic that is poorly understood despite the fact that in many countries the majority of indigenous people today reside in urban areas. Furthermore, the research will contribute to scientific understandings of how urban planning and new built environments can have impacts on processes such as cultural change and economic marginalization. This research will be of interest to scholars, architects, urban planners, and policymakers.

por.por_cntn:
This study was an attempt to understand sociocultural and economic transformations caused by urban planning initiatives targeted at urban indigenous populations. The study was conducted in Taiwan. Since the 1990s, Taipei’s suburban municipality of New Taipei City has been relocating many indigenous squatter communities built on its peripheries with the goal of increasing the employability of their residents, stabilizing their income, and regulating their unpermitted use of state-owned land. Through conducting empirical, ethnographic research with city officials, architects, indigenous community residents, among others, this study ethnographically followed changes brought about by the relocation of urban indigenous squatter communities to new locations, in realms such as human relatedness, financial responsibilities, and the usage of urban space. It also investigated how various actors are imagining how to build a better urban environment in which urbanized indigenous people can flourish with their rights protected by the city and the state.

As a result of sixteen months of field research, this research project has discovered that there exists a significant gap between what city officials and architects imagine as possible (positive) effects of relocation on indigenous squatters and actual changes that relocation has brought to the livelihoods of indigenous relocatees, especially at the public housing complex to which one urban indigenous squatter community was relocated in the early 2000s. State-led efforts to transform urban indigenous subjects into self-reliant, stably-employed, propertied urban citizens by relocating them from squatter settlements did not produce the desired effects. Many indigenous relocatees have continued to live in the public housing complex well beyond the six year limit that city officials initially set, unable to find stable employment or affordable housing elsewhere. At the same time, many relocatees refuse to completely give up their claims to the land they were relocated from. They have returned to the urban state-owned land where their original community once stood and continued to engage in gardening, foraging, hunting, and fishing there. Relocation has ironically engendered new encroachments on state-owned land. 

While the recent relocation projects to “park areas for indigenous livelihoods and cultures,” communities which will incorporate distinct indigenous traditions and cultures into their design, are seen as better alternatives to relocations to public housing complexes, this research can foresee that many similar issues would arise even in this new type of relocation site. While input from residents does inform their design (through using the method of “participatory planning”), these park areas are, spatially speaking, much smaller than the current communities, limiting space for improvisational design and use both for architects and residents. The new communities have little space where residents can engage in gardening, foraging, and hunting, which might result in residents simply using their original territory for such activities. Additionally, residents will be heavily indebted for long time to come to cover the construction costs for the new communities.

This project’s research findings will make important contributions to anthropological research on contemporary indigenous experience and how it is shaped by the local and global regimes of indigenous rights and recognition. While anthropological debates on indigenous rights have mostly centered on citizenship and rights arising from indigenous peoples’ deep connections and ties to their indigenous territories and lands, this project sheds light on emerging forms of indigenous rights and recognition conferred on indigenous subjects who have migrated to urban areas. As indigenous populations urbanize in various locales, many municipalities and cities are grappling with how indigenous rights and citizenship can be extended to indigenous subjects who are no in places they are not indigenous to. This project’s results elucidate the difficulties and complexities involved in such attempts to recognize and protect specifically urban indigenous rights. They will be of use for scholars, policymakers, and activists grappling with similar issues in Taiwan and other contexts with large urban indigenous populations.

Additionally, this research project can contribute to important debates on the right to the city and urban social movements taking place in disciplines such as geography and urban planning. Many geographers and urban planners are concerned with how basic rights such as access to infrastructure and housing can be ensured and protected for urban residents in today’s world, where the majority of the world’s population resides in urban areas. This research will contribute to their debates by emphasizing how the right to engage in distinct cultural activities needs to be also an important aspect of “the right to the city”.

This research project also has the possibility of having an impact on urban planning decisions made by policymakers and planners in the Taipei region and beyond. By pointing out gaps between the intentions of those who have designed relocation projects and their unintended consequences on urban indigenous livelihoods, policymakers might be persuaded to reconsider their decision-making processes regarding how spaces suited for urban indigenous people can be designed and promoted.
